column3: A simple weave, with each poi doing one downbeat on opposite sides of the body
column4: Try to keep the poi perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the sides of your body
column5: As you get more comfortable, try to spin slower
column6: It is encouraged to learn both the "left hand over" & "right hand over" variations (refer to video)
column7: Dont be afraid to exaggerate your arm movements as much as possible so you dont hit yourself when the poi crosses to the other side (applies to all other weaves and n beat moves)

column3: Both poi spin in the same direction in split time to the side of the body
column4: Try to keep the poi perpendicular to the floor and parallel to each other
column5: The poi should be spinning in split time; when one poi is pointing down, the other is pointing up
column6: Its easier to start learning the move with shorter poi; we can do this by partially wrapping the poi in our arms (applies to corkscrew)

column3: Same time, same direction done with both hands together
column4: The planes of each hand are on a slight slant to prevent the poi from hitting each other
column5: Start with your hands farther apart and work your way to getting them right next to each other
column6: It may be easier to learn the move in split time first so the poi dont hit each other, then purposely let the timing sync up until you get into same time

column3: Both poi switch spin direction through the turning the body
column4: Point your wrists down while turning
column5: This move is in same time so both poi should point downwards at the same time
column6: Practice two beat spins with either hand pointing to either the left or the ride side of your body until you are able to move the motions closer to your body (applies to windmill and watermill)

column3: A two beat weave done in floor plane
column4: Your hands should be pointing in opposite directions at all times
column5: Imagine each poi making a figure 8, alternating between top and bottom. Additioanlly, one poi always follows the other's path.

column3: A wrap that hits the forearm
column4: Aim to hit your arm an inch above the top of the glowstick; there's a sweet spot that shouldn't hurt your arm

column3: A simple weave, with each poi doing one downbeat on one side of the body and two downbeats on the opposite side of the body
column4: Try to keep the poi perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the sides of your body
column5: As you get more comfortable, try to spin slower
column6: This also applies to 2 beat weaves, but imagine each poi tracing the lines of an "X" when they go in front of you

column3: Similar to the 3 beat weave, but in reverse
column4: This is the only move that has a "reverse" page because it is usually the first move you learn in reverse. Almost every move after this has a reverse version.

column3: A two beat weave done above the head in wall plane
column4: Because this is one of the first moves that is learned in wall plane, it will take time to get used to spinning your poi without slanting
column5: One of the most difficult parts of this move is getting it into split time. Count beats in your head if it helps.
column6: Most of the move should be done through wrist movement
column7: You can do same time shoulder reels first, and then purposely let the timing unsync untill you get into split time (applies to hip reels in watermill)

column3: A windmill, but the front beats are opened up
column4: Opening the arms up may feel uncomfortable, but you can practice it with one hand at a time

column3: A windmill by the hips
column4: Both wrists should point inward when the poi goes behind you
column5: Make sure that the timing is split time. You can count in your head for this.

column3: A combination of a hip and shoulder reel turns
column4: Both poi should be in same time (downbeats are at the same time)
column5: Be comfortable with reel turns

column3: A wrap that hits the bicep
column4: Make sure that your arm is bent perpendicular to your body (not outwards)

column3: A wrap that hits the shin
column4: Balance. Goes well with a side of chicken (wrap)!

column3: A combination of the forward and reverse 3 beat and windmill
column4: A difficult part of this move is the transition from r3b to windmill. If you end your r3b in front of you, the windmill should start behind you and vice versa.
column5: Spend as much time as you need at each section of the fountain. You can always cut down how long you spend at each part as you get more comfortable.

column3: A wrap where both poi converge around the hands
column4: Both poi should be spinning in the same direction with wall planes bent slightly inward
column5: When entering a spiral wrap, let go of the string between your fingertips so it can naturally wrap around your hands

column3: A wrap that hits the tricep behind the body
column4: Shove your arm behind you (pretend you are elbowing someone) and wrap on your tricep)

column3: A movement with poi that restricts movement to the bottom half of the spin
column4: This move is relatively simple, but takes a lot of practice to clean. Keep the pendulums as controlled as you can.
column5: swing swong

column3: A 3 petal antispin flower done with each hand, pointed outwards from the center
column4: Frontals are a two downbeat move. If you count when the poi faces downwards (6 o'clock) you should be able to count 2 per cycle.
column5: Frontals are one of the first moves people learn that allow them to practice against a wall; if you do so managing planes becomes way easier.

column3: A combination of both hands doing bicep wraps on top of the arms
column4: Your arms must be perpendicular to your body when performing bicep wraps can VB vn
column5: Most of the movement comes from the wrists so focus on wrist movement

column3: A combination of both hands doing bicep wraps below the arms
column4: Your arms must be perpendicular to your body when performing bicep wraps
column5: Most of the movement comes from the wrists so focus on wrist movement

column3: A figure 8 drawn with crossed arms in wall plane
column4: Both hands are each doing a two beat but are on opposite sides of the body
column5: Each poi should alternate between being in front of your body and behind
column6: Practice with one poi wrapped in your hand at a time

column3: A two petal flower where the direction of spin of the poi is the same as the movement of the arm
column4: Both "spins" within the inspin should be on a cardinal. Keep the spins controlled!

column3: Crossers, but with the front beats opened up (similar to vitruvian)
column4: Both of your arms at some point should be full extended, with the other bent.
column5: Each arm should alternate tracing the other arm

column3: A 3 petal antispin flower hybrid with an extension
column4: Draw an equilateral triangle with your hand and make sure to accentuate the top petal
column5: Focus on always having equidistance from your belly button to either bottom petal. At first, it will result in smaller triquetras, but when you are more comfortable you can increase the size of the pattern.

column3: A 4 petal antispin flower that hits each cardinal direction
column4: The most important part of this move is to make sure that each cardinal direction is properly aligned
column5: It may help to practice in front of a mirror
column6: 4 petal antispins have 3 downbeats, similar to how a triquetra has 2 downbeats. You should be able to count 3 times when the poi head points downwards

column3: A fountain similar to a regular 4x4 fountain but backward
column4: There is only one beat for each hand per cardinal direction
column5: imagine alternating between forward and reverse 2 beat weaves, except you change the levels of your hands
column6: If your doing this move correctly your hands will alternate between right and left on top when you pass through the middle

column3: A combination of half an antispin and an extension
column4: Pretend you are only doing half of an antispin and do an extension back to where your hand started
column5: Bend your arms slightly

column3: A body tracer combining parts of a snake and an extension
column4: This hard part of this move is the same as the movement for a snake. If you are having trouble with this move, try learning the snake first.
column5: Each hand should be alternating cycles (one hand tucks in front of you while the other tucks behind you)

column3: Both poi spin in the same direction and meet up on the left and right, but the hands move in opposite directions.
column4: Focus on getting the east and west cardinal lined up

column3: A sequence of pendulums that don't require you to move your hand
column4: Align both pendulums such that they create a straight line

column3: A combination of pendulums and parts of antispins
column4: If you are comfortable with pendulums, focus on the timing and try to get the top pendulum in sync

column3: Both poi tangle and are pulled to create a fast spinning buzzsaw
column4: The point at which the strings tangle should be the same distance from the poi/handle
column5: If you look at orbitals/ airwraps/ hyperloops from the side, you will notice that the poi paths arent parallel. One poi is slightly skewed so that theres a greater chance of the poi being able to cross paths and initiate the tangle.

column3: Both poi tangle and untangle in wall plane
column4: The point at which the strings tangle should be the same distance from the poi/handle
column5: Don't try to force the untangle; if your planes are correct, they should untangle automatically

column3: A weave that involves spinning poi behind the back
column4: This move requires a lot of practice with each hand separately
column5: Try keeping one poi spin behind you in wall plane without hitting anything
column6: You will hit yourself less if you turn your torso more

column3: A body tracer behind your back, along the arm
column4: It may be difficult to contort your body but try to get the poi in same time to make the move look clean

column3: A mercedes (triquetra) done along with a pendulum instead of an extension
column4: Align the pendulum such that it creates a straight line with the top petal of the triquetra

column3: Two antispin flowers spinning in the same direction that cross over and extend back
column4: Much of the difficulty from this move comes from the potential of the poi hitting each other or tangling. Note that the poi should be on slightly different wall planes
column5: Each hand performs a complete antispin before extending back.

column3: Two antispin flowers spinning in opposite directions that alternate extensions
column4: Practice each hand separately. It is important that you can do at least one hand without thinking so you can focus on the other.

column3: Triquetras that follow the hand path of a static spin
column4: You need to be comfortable with performing extremely fast triquetras
column5: The static spinning poi follows the same path as the triquetra arm (both the arm and the poi should be right next to each other)

column3: An extended airwrap
column4: The point at which the strings tangle should be the same distance from the poi/handle
column5: You can sustain the tangle by rotating your arms in the same direction the poi are moving
column6: If you spin slower than normal, the extry + exit motion becomes easier to process (it usually happens p fast)

column3: A normal C CAP, but with a snake variant instead of an extension
column4: If you are familiar with other body tracers such as snakes, this move combines a simple body tracer with a CAP

column3: An antispin inspin hybrid, with parts of it behind the body
column4: Both the antispin and inspin are performed behind you at the same time at a point in the move. Get comfortable with performing flowers behind you!
column5: Dont be afraid to extend your arms up + out as much as possible to make sure both flowers dont hit each other. Also find a big area with a tall ceiling to practice this move.

column3: A one petal vertical flower
column4: Your hand should follow the path of a static spin

column3: A form of a CAP that goes through each C CAP for each cardinal
column4: Practice each CAP (northern, eastern, western, and southern) separately
column5: One hand performs a normal 4 petal antispin while the other focuses on CAPs

column3: Both poi spin in opposite directions and make a zigzag pattern crossing each cardinal
column4: Practice antispins with varying speeds

column3: Both hands spin in opposite directions and form a northern and southern triangle
column4: You need to be very comfortable with antispins to be able to be able to perform this move

column3: The rotation of the poi such that the hand follows the path of the poi. Looks like a static spin, but is significantly harder.
column4: Your hand and poi should both be rotating about a center point

column3: A one petal horizontal flower
column4: This move is much more difficult that cateyes because of gravity is actively working against you
column5: Your hand should follow the path of a static spin

column3: One of the basic moves; the staff makes 2 down beats on each side of the arm. Has both forward and reverse directions.
column4: Count each time an end of the staff passes your arm; there should be two consecutive passes on each side of the arm
column5: Divide the move into 4 postitions: (thumb end inside far/pinky end outside close)/(thumb end inside close/pinky end outside far)/(thumb end outside far/pinky end inside close)/(thumb end outside close pinky end inside far)
column6: Keep your arm as straight as possible so that you don't hit yourself.

column3: The other basic move; the staff makes three down beats on each side of the body.
column4: Curl the staff so it can lie flat on your palm and forearm; once in this position/move the staff to a vertical position
column5: Move your shoulder back/and uncurl the staff until your hand is fist down and palm facing out
column6: Twist your body in order to bring the pinky end of the staff to the front of your body first/then repeat from beginning

column3: This move passes the staff around the body with 3 beat.
column4: Practice 3 beat on both left and right hands. This move uses 3 beat to transition between the front and the back of the body
column5: Practice passing separately; get into the motion of passing an object around your body
column6: Don't think of it as passing it to your other hand think of it as handing to it mid rotation.

column3: Transitioning between forward and reverse 2 beat on each side of the body
column4: Try to exaggerate the transition at first; instead of going directly across the body/draw a circle with the tip of the staff.
column5: Start transitioning when your palm is facing up.
column6: When starting out fully pivoting on your toes to exagerate the position helps. As you become more comfortable with the movement stop pivoting to make it look smoother

column3: On the side of the body; staff spins up and down
column4: It's literally the second half of 3 beat; instead of curling it up in front of your body/curl it up and down at the side of your body
column5: Focus on the positioning of your elbows so the roation of the staff doesn't hit your inner arm and stop. Make sure the staff passes your forearm on the indised of your body.
column6: For a cleaner looking cap, learn how to stop your staff when it's perfectly vertical. A fast movement into a stiff vertical position is ideal.

column3: A 2 beat while the arm moves in a circle
column4: Start 2 beat first/when comfortable/start moving the arm in the same direction the staff is spinning
column5: Try to keep the speed of both the arm and the staff steady
column6: Make sure to extend your arms wide for a decently sized circle. Exaggerate the width as much as you can, but make sure that you don't forgoe technique as a result!

column3: A pinwheel but the pass in front is above your head
column4: Instead of completing the 3 beat/use CAPs to bring the staff above your head/then use 2 beat to pass between your hands
column5: This movement should be very fluid to give the illusion of undisturbed rotation. Practice fluidity before practicing speed.
column6: While learning this move by stopping for a second when you reach the top is good to get the movement down, when doing this movement in shows you want to eliminate that pause as much as possible. It helps to loosen your grip slightly or move your arm with the staff as it continues down the pinwheel.

column3: Spinning a staff on an open palm horizontally over your head
column4: Looking up at your hand may help it be more horizontal.
column5: Try to balance it for as long as you can by tilting your palm back and forth.
column6: Speed actually helps with balance in this case. A faster spinning staff is easier to balance because it's carrying its own weight a little bit when it's spinning faster.

column3: One down beat on each side of the arm
column4: Each end of the staff does not pass to the other side of the arm; each end of the staff stays on its side of the arm.
column5: Basically pen spinning/except its with a 3ft long stick and your arm
column6: The wrist is more important in this movement than the arm. It's actually a great move to do if you're aiming to increase wrist fluidity and speed.

column3: A horizontal 1 beat
column4: Make sure the ends of the staff don't cross your arm.
column5: Keep your wrist loose, that's the primary location of movement.
column6: This is another great move to practice when aiming to increase wrist fluidity and improve planes with your wrist.

column3: A 1 beat around your head
column4: One end of the staff should pass in front of your head/and the other end should pass behind your head.
column5: Move your hand back and forth instead of your head.
column6: To get used to contorting your arm the way you need to, start by placing your hand near the end of the staff you're spinning from. That way, the staff becomes more like a string and your arm can perform the contortion easier. From there, move your hand closer to the middle of the staff as you get used to it.

column3: A windmill but you extend out.
column4: Extend your arm as much as possible.
column5: This movement looks best with large, emphasized circles, much like the stringing version of this move, so don't forget that when you're performing.
column6: Placing your hand a little farther away from the center of the staff helps a little bit with this.

column3: Throw a staff in the air while it spins parallel to your body
column4: Enter from 3 beat; wait until the staff is parallel to the ground/then push upwards
column5: Don't just flick your hand because it'll make the staff spin faster but it won't go as high
column6: The wrist controls the spin, while the arm controls the height. It's a good combination of the two that gets you clean tosses.

column3: Throw a staff in the air from corkscrew
column4: Start in corkscrew; when your palm is facing up/push upwards.
column5: Just like a regular toss, your arm controls the height while your wrist controls the spins. Keeping the two in balance will get you a successful toss and easy catch.
column6: Again, keep your wrist loose for fluidity.

column3: A pass under your leg into a toss
column4: A regular toss/except you spin the staff under your leg and then toss
column5: Don't over-complicate this move. It really is just a toss from under your leg. The same technique applies, just lift your leg in the process.

column3: Yeet the staff across a large distance to another person
column4: Synchronize with your partner and hope for the best
column5: You need to not only be in sync with your partner to the T if you hope to pull this off, but you need to practicing positioning, spacing, and toss height. Everything a good staff tossed does well is essential to pulling off this move.
column6: This move is the definition of "high risk, high reward." That being said, you're going to want this move to take center stage when you do it in a set, otherwise there isn't a point in risking so much for it.

column3: Similar to 3 beat/but it goes over your shoulder.
column4: Your elbow draws a circle over your shoulder.

column3: The staff rolls over your hand.
column4: Have your thumb under the staff and use it to flick the staff over your hand.

column3: Antispin where the ends of the staff point to 4 distinct points
column4: Make sure the end of the staff actually stops at each point.
column5: The thumb end makes a horizontal line/while the pinky end makes a vertical line

column3: 5 beat/except with two hands/split time
column4: Practice 5 beat on both hands/then combine

column3: Vitruvian/except with two hands
column4: Practice vitruvian on both hands/and both directions.
column5: Double Vitruvian can be both split time and same time/as well as going in both directions

column3: A staffing emulation of stringing frontals
column4: They are split time opposite 4-petal antispins/so work on those first
column5: As both hands have the same amount of beats/try to synchronize the beats

column3: The tip of one staff drags the tip of the other staff around the head/and vice versa at the waist
column4: Practice doing windmill and 1 beat on the wall plane at your hip
column5: Do it slowly and keep the connecting tips in as close proximity as possible

column3: The staff spins around a fixed/central point
column4: This move can be done both pinky or thumb end in/whichever way is more comfortable
column5: Keep your focus on the position that you want the staff to circle around

column3: A staffing emulation of stringing Chase the Sun/Moon
column4: The arm behind your body does a 3 beat while the arm in front of your body does a 2 beat
column5: Essentially/this is a pair of modified Vitruvians spinning synchronously

column3: A staffing emulation of stringing No Beat
column4: Hold on to the end of the staff and spin them so they are opposite to each other
column5: When your arms are going to cross/toss the staff in the hand that is approaching from the bottom/then move that hand on top and catch the same end of the staff

column3: Same time opposite 4 beat antispins
column4: The thumb end of the staffs are always nearly touching each other

column3: Toss the staff, spin yourself quickly, then catch the staff.
column4: The key here is to spin in the same direction you're throwing the staff. In other words, don't toss the staff from your right hand, then spin towards the left. Spin in the direction of the arm you toss from, that way you and the staff are spinning together
column5: A decently sized toss is needed to pull this move off. Give yourself time to spin completely, then stop and balance yourself before you catch your toss.
column6: Toss as STRAIGHT in the air as possible, and spin as tightly as you can so you don't wander away from your original position.

column3: Essentially a lace around the leg
column4: You are essentially taking a body lace and transferring to a leg, your hand movements stay the same or similar! Don't overthink it
column5: Once you have learned your torso and leg lace, practice transitioning to and from both.
column6: You can perform this move on one or both legs

column3: A beginner transition from one leg to the other. Feels like you are weaving the whip back and forth.
column4: Remember the concept of the Open Torso Position, the Open Position can be used in any type of lacing move; when you are able to go to Open position, you will be able to move your hands and close on another body part to finish your transition!

column3: A beginner move which is mostly used as a transition around the body in which you lace the whip up your arm and around the elbow.
column4: This is mainly used to transition from your torso lace to upper-body laces in a smooth manner

column3: Essentially a lace around the arm
column4: This move looks good if you continously lace while moving your arm around your body, otherwise it is mainly used as a transition.
column5: To avoid tangling your whip, make your circles large

column3: Essentially a lace around the neck.
column4: To make this move look snazzier, we usually use the elbow lace to transition into the neck lace and raise our elbows again to transition out of this move.
column5: This move can easily get caught in neck sweat and can chafe your skin so it helps to protect your neck.

column3: Slowly squat down with knees outwards and wrap from right knee to left knee (or vice versa)
column4: Release your inner Khandy.
column5: Maintain a wide squat (if you're comfortable with it!)

column3: This move is extremely important and central to all Body-Lacing moves. A basic/smooth wrap around the waist.
column4: It is important to NOT let go of the whip handle; the handle should always stay in your dominant hand.
column5: Make sure you are attentive visually; you may think you are doing the right thing when you aren't.
column6: Once you can do lace by gripping with your fingers, slowly transition to lacing with your WRIST; this will create for smoother/flowier laces.
column7: This move is extremely important and central to all Body-Lacing moves.

column3: A lace around a bent-knee while kicking out when the time is right to create a mix between a lace and a lash
column4: Repeat the move to see when the timing is good for you!
column5: Make sure you tuck/bend your knee to the extreme so the whip can wrap well

column3: 3 Beat derived from Poi/Glowsticking
column4: Watch 3 Beat Weave videos from PlayPoi or DrexFactorPoi

column3: Essentially a 2 beat weave above the head
column4: Refer to Poi/Glowsticking teachers or videos

column3: Combines the 3 Beat Weaves and Windmill to make a Fountain
column4: Same concept as Single Whip Fountain but with another Whip doing split-time!

column3: Starting with a closed torso lace, whip outwards and then above and then back into a torso lace
column4: Your first whiplash move! This means you are holding onto the handle with one hand while the fibers are flying around you! Be careful and wear protective clothes, this skillset might hurt!

column3: A move integrated from the Poi/Glowsticking arts, directing the whip between the two parallels
column4: Learning a 2 Beat Whiplash is easier for most on the whips compared to glowsticking (because of the increased control), you can indirectly learn how to string through whipping!

column3: A move integrated from the Poi/Glowsticking arts, directing the whip between the two parallels
Essentially combines the 2 Beat Whiplashes smoothly creating a single handed Fountain!
column4: Make sure you move your body with the whip so you avoid hitting yourself

column3: Whiplash wrapping around an arm and then whiplashes out
column4: Very similar to wrapping concept in Glowsticking

column3: 2 whips spinning BOTH inwards OR outwards at the same time
Fiberwield and spin under the knee and back
column4: Make sure you EXAGGERATE this move so you don't get hurt

column3: An advanced neck wrap
column4: This is a VERY advanced move! Please make sure someone is with you and that you are wearing the appropriate gear when you practice! You have been warned.
column5: Fiberwield and wrap the whip around the neck a couple of times and then unwrap

column3: Fiberwielding spin around the arm and back
3 Beat Reverse derived from Poi/Glowsticking
column4: Watch 3 Beat Weave videos from PlayPoi or DrexFactorPoi

column3: Same as a 2 Beat Whiplash but shift control from handle to fibers
Same as a 2 Beat Whiplash but shift control from handle to fibers
Fountain holding fibers and NOT handle
